originalTools.name: zapier__add_tools
originalTools.description: Add new actions to your MCP provider

originalTools.name: zapier__edit_tools
originalTools.description: Edit your existing MCP provider actions

originalTools.name: zapier__gmail_get_attachment_by_filename
originalTools.description: Retrieves a specific Gmail message attachment by Filename.

originalTools.name: zapier__gmail_add_label_to_email
originalTools.description: Add a label to an email message.

originalTools.name: zapier__gmail_delete_email
originalTools.description: Sends an email message to the trash.

originalTools.name: zapier__gmail_create_draft_reply
originalTools.description: Create a draft reply to an existing email.

originalTools.name: zapier__gmail_send_email
originalTools.description: Create and send a new email message.

originalTools.name: zapier__gmail_remove_label_from_email
originalTools.description: Remove a label from an email message.

originalTools.name: zapier__gmail_remove_label_from_conversation
originalTools.description: Remove a specified label from all emails within a conversation.

originalTools.name: zapier__gmail_reply_to_email
originalTools.description: Send a reply to an email message.

subTools.name: Find Unread Emails
subTools.description: Find all unread emails in the inbox. Returns email details including sender, subject, date, and message IDs for further processing.

inputs.name: instructions
inputs.description: Additional instructions for filtering unread emails

outputFields.name: id
outputFields.description: Unique message ID for use in other operations

outputFields.name: date
outputFields.description: Date and time email was received

outputFields.name: labels
outputFields.description: Gmail labels applied to this email

outputFields.name: message_url
outputFields.description: Direct URL to open email in Gmail

subTools.name: Find Emails By Sender
subTools.description: Search for emails from a specific sender. Returns all matching emails with full details.

inputs.name: sender_email
inputs.description: Email address of the sender to search for

subTools.name: Find Emails With Attachments
subTools.description: Find emails that have file attachments. Returns email details and attachment information including filenames and sizes.

subTools.name: Find Emails By Category
subTools.description: Find emails in a specific Gmail category (Updates, Promotions, Social, Personal, Forums).

subTools.name: Get Email Full Details
subTools.description: Get complete details of a single email including full body content. Use for reading email contents.

inputs.name: search_criteria
inputs.description: Gmail search query to find the specific email

inputs.name: instructions
inputs.description: Instructions describing which email to find

outputFields.name: from
outputFields.description: Sender info with name and email

outputExample.subject: Important Security Update
outputExample.body_plain: A critical vulnerability has been disclosed...

subTools.name: Create Gmail Label
subTools.description: Create a new Gmail label for organizing emails. Returns the label ID which can be used to apply this label to emails.

inputs.name: label_name
inputs.description: Name for the new label. Use / for nested labels (e.g., 'Work/Projects')

outputFields.name: id
outputFields.description: Label ID for use in add_label_to_email

outputFields.name: messageListVisibility
outputFields.description: Whether label shows in message list

outputFields.name: labelListVisibility
outputFields.description: Whether label shows in label list

subTools.name: Star Email
subTools.description: Add a star to an email message for easy reference later.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the message_id of the email to star

inputs.name: message_id
inputs.description: ID of the email to star (from find_email)

outputFields.name: labelIds
outputFields.description: All labels now on the email

subTools.name: Mark Email as Important
subTools.description: Mark an email as important in Gmail.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the message_id of the email to mark

inputs.name: message_id
inputs.description: ID of the email to mark important

outputFields.name: labelIds
outputFields.description: All labels now on the email

subTools.name: Apply Custom Label to Email
subTools.description: Apply a custom label to an email. Requires creating the label first or knowing the label ID.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the message_id of the email
To get or create the custom label ID

inputs.name: message_id
inputs.description: ID of the email to label

outputFields.name: labelIds
outputFields.description: All labels now on the email

subTools.name: Mark Email as Read
subTools.description: Mark an email as read by removing the UNREAD label.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the message_id of the unread email

inputs.name: message_id
inputs.description: ID of the email to mark as read

subTools.name: Remove Star from Email
subTools.description: Remove the star from a starred email.

inputs.name: message_id
inputs.description: ID of the email to unstar

subTools.name: Archive Email
subTools.description: Archive an email by removing it from the inbox. The email remains accessible via search or labels.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the message_id of the email to archive

inputs.name: message_id
inputs.description: ID of the email to archive

subTools.name: Mark Entire Conversation as Read
subTools.description: Mark all emails in a conversation thread as read.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the thread_id of the conversation

inputs.name: instructions
inputs.default: Mark this entire conversation as read

outputFields.name: messages
outputFields.description: All messages in thread with updated labels

subTools.name: Archive Entire Conversation
subTools.description: Archive all emails in a conversation by removing the INBOX label from all messages.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the thread_id of the conversation

inputs.name: thread_id
inputs.description: Thread ID of the conversation to archive

subTools.name: Create Email Draft
subTools.description: Create a draft email that can be reviewed and sent later from Gmail.

subTools.name: Create Draft Reply
subTools.description: Create a draft reply to an existing email conversation. The draft is linked to the original thread.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the thread_id of the email to reply to

inputs.name: thread_id
inputs.description: Thread ID of the conversation to reply to

inputs.name: instructions
inputs.description: Instructions for creating the reply draft
inputs.default: Create a draft reply to this conversation

subTools.name: Reply to Email
subTools.description: Send a reply to an existing email conversation. The reply is linked to the original thread and sent immediately.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the thread_id and sender's email address

inputs.name: thread_id
inputs.description: Thread ID of the conversation to reply to

inputs.name: subject
inputs.description: Override subject (defaults to Re: original subject)

inputs.name: instructions
inputs.default: Send a reply to this email

subTools.name: Send New Email
subTools.description: Compose and send a new email immediately. Creates a new conversation thread.

subTools.name: Delete Email (Move to Trash)
subTools.description: Move an email to the Trash folder. The email can be recovered from Trash within 30 days.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the message_id of the email to delete

inputs.name: message_id
inputs.description: ID of the email to move to trash

subTools.name: Get Email Attachment
subTools.description: Download a specific attachment from an email by filename. Returns a download URL for the file.

requiresFirst.reason: To get the message_id and exact attachment filename

inputs.name: message_id
inputs.description: ID of the email containing the attachment

inputs.name: attachment_filename
inputs.description: Exact filename of the attachment to download

documentedInputs.description: This tool takes no inputs - it returns a configuration URL
documentedInputs.notes: Returns a URL to the Zapier MCP configuration interface for adding new actions

documentedInputs.description: Natural language instructions for what email to find. Parameters not explicitly provided will be guessed from these instructions.
examples: Find the most recent email in my inbox
documentedInputs.notes: This field guides the AI to fill in missing parameters

documentedInputs.description: Gmail's advanced search query syntax for finding emails
documentedInputs.notes: Supports Gmail's full search syntax including sender, recipient, subject, labels, dates, sizes, attachments, and boolean operators

documentedInputs.description: Name of the Gmail label to create
documentedInputs.notes: Can use forward slash (/) to create nested labels. Label names must be unique.

source.description: First call zapier__gmail_find_email to get the message ID

documentedInputs.description: Array of label IDs to add to the email
documentedInputs.notes: System labels use uppercase IDs. Custom labels use the label ID returned from create_label or are looked up dynamically.

source.description: First call zapier__gmail_find_email to get the message ID

documentedInputs.description: Array of label IDs to remove from the email
documentedInputs.notes: System labels use uppercase IDs. Custom labels use the label ID from creation.

source.description: First call zapier__gmail_find_email to get the message ID

documentedInputs.notes: Archiving removes the INBOX label, keeping the email accessible but out of the inbox

source.description: First call zapier__gmail_find_email to get the message ID

documentedInputs.notes: Moves the email to trash. Does not permanently delete.

source.description: First call zapier__gmail_find_email with has:attachment query to get a message with attachments
The filename comes from the attachment list in find_email results

documentedInputs.description: Size of the attachment to retrieve
documentedInputs.notes: Can be obtained from find_email results

documentedInputs.description: Recipients of the email. Must be valid, real email addresses - do not use fake addresses.

documentedInputs.description: CC recipients. Must be valid, real email addresses.
documentedInputs.notes: Can be comma-separated

documentedInputs.description: Natural language instructions for what email to find. Parameters not explicitly provided will be guessed from these instructions.
examples: Find the most recent email in my inbox
documentedInputs.notes: This field guides the AI to fill in missing parameters

documentedInputs.description: Gmail's advanced search query syntax for finding emails
documentedInputs.notes: Supports Gmail's full search syntax including sender, recipient, subject, labels, dates, sizes, attachments, categories, and boolean operators

documentedInputs.description: Name of the Gmail label to create
documentedInputs.notes: Can use forward slash (/) to create nested labels. Label names must be unique. Returns the label ID needed for adding labels to emails.

source.description: First call zapier__gmail_find_email to get the message ID

documentedInputs.description: Array of label IDs to add to the email. Can be system labels or custom label IDs.
documentedInputs.notes: System labels use uppercase. Custom labels use the ID returned from gmail_create_label (e.g., 'Label_1')

source.description: First call zapier__gmail_find_email to get the message ID

documentedInputs.description: Array of label IDs to remove from the email
documentedInputs.notes: Use custom label IDs (e.g., 'Label_1') to remove custom labels

source.description: First call zapier__gmail_find_email to get the message ID

documentedInputs.notes: Archiving removes the INBOX label, keeping the email accessible via search or labels but out of the main inbox

source.description: First call zapier__gmail_find_email to get the thread ID

documentedInputs.notes: Thread ID groups all emails in a conversation. Often same as message_id for single-email threads.

documentedInputs.description: Array of label IDs to remove from ALL emails in the conversation

documentedInputs.description: Recipients of the email. Must be valid, real email addresses.
documentedInputs.notes: Can include multiple recipients. Do not use fake addresses like @example.com - look up in CRM or contact book if needed.

documentedInputs.description: CC recipients
documentedInputs.notes: Carbon copy recipients who receive a copy of the email

documentedInputs.description: BCC recipients (hidden from other recipients)
documentedInputs.notes: Blind carbon copy - recipients not visible to others

Use HTML tags for formatting like

,

documentedInputs.notes: The name shown to recipients

documentedInputs.notes: By default, drafts get the DRAFT label

documentedInputs.description: Email signature to append
documentedInputs.notes: Use 'default' for your Gmail default signature

documentedInputs.description: File attachments to include
documentedInputs.notes: URLs to files to attach to the email

workflows.userTask: Help me triage my inbox - find unread emails, mark important ones, and archive newsletters

steps.purpose: Get all unread emails to review
Categorize emails by type and importance
steps.logic: Review step1 results - identify: (1) emails from real people vs automated, (2) promotional/newsletter vs transactional, (3) urgent items requiring response

steps.purpose: Mark important emails that need attention

inputMapping.message_id: IDs of emails identified as important in step 2

steps.purpose: Archive promotional emails and newsletters after review

inputMapping.message_id: IDs of promotional emails from step 2

steps.purpose: Mark processed emails as read

inputMapping.message_id: IDs of emails that don't need action

workflows.answerTemplate: I found {step1.count} unread emails. {step3.count} were marked as important, {step4.count} newsletters/promos were archived, and {step5.count} were marked as read. Your remaining inbox items need your attention.
decisionPoints: If email is from a real person (not automated), mark as important
If email is promotional/newsletter and older than 24 hours, archive it
If email is a receipt or confirmation, mark as read but keep in inbox
If email contains 'urgent' or 'action required', flag for immediate attention

workflows.userTask: Find all invoice and receipt emails from the past month and get the PDF attachments

steps.purpose: Find recent emails with attachments that might be invoices

inputMapping.instructions: Find emails with PDF attachments from the past month containing invoice or receipt

steps.purpose: Filter to actual invoice/receipt emails
steps.logic: Review subjects and senders from step1 - keep only those with subjects containing 'invoice', 'receipt', 'payment', 'billing' or from known billing addresses

steps.purpose: Download each invoice PDF
Label processed invoices for organization

workflows.answerTemplate: Found {step2.count} invoice/receipt emails from the past month. Downloaded {step3.count} PDF attachments. Here are the download links: {step3.attachments}
decisionPoints: Only process emails with PDF attachments (not images)
Prioritize emails from known billing providers
If multiple attachments exist, get the one with 'invoice' or 'receipt' in filename

workflows.userTask: Find the most recent important email that needs a response and draft a reply for me to review

steps.purpose: Find unread emails that might need responses

inputMapping.instructions: Find unread emails from real people (not automated/noreply)

steps.purpose: Identify the most important email needing a response
steps.logic: From step1 results, prioritize: (1) emails with questions, (2) emails from known contacts, (3) emails with time-sensitive language. Exclude automated emails (noreply, notifications, etc.)

steps.purpose: Get full content of the selected email
Draft an appropriate reply based on email content
steps.logic: Analyze the email content, identify key points that need addressing, compose a professional response

steps.purpose: Create the draft reply in Gmail

workflows.answerTemplate: I found an email from {step3.from.name} with subject '{step3.subject}' that needs a response. I've drafted a reply for you to review in your Gmail drafts.
decisionPoints: If email is a question, draft an answer or ask clarifying questions
If email is a meeting request, acknowledge and confirm availability
If email is feedback, thank them and address specific points
Always keep draft professional and concise

workflows.userTask: Find all emails from a specific sender and organize them - keep recent ones, archive old ones

steps.purpose: Find all emails from the specified sender

inputMapping.sender_email: User provides the sender email address
inputMapping.instructions: Find all emails from this sender

steps.purpose: Categorize emails by age and importance
steps.logic: Split step1 results into: (1) last 7 days - keep in inbox, (2) 7-30 days - review for importance, (3) 30+ days - candidates for archive

steps.purpose: Archive old emails from this sender

inputMapping.message_id: IDs of emails older than 30 days from step 2

steps.purpose: Create a label for this sender if needed
Apply the sender label to remaining emails

inputMapping.message_id: IDs of recent emails from step 2

workflows.answerTemplate: Found {step1.count} emails from {sender}. Archived {step3.count} old emails (30+ days). Created label '{step4.name}' and applied it to {step5.count} recent emails for easy filtering.
decisionPoints: Keep emails less than 7 days old in inbox
Archive emails older than 30 days unless starred or important
Create sender-specific label for frequent correspondents
If sender is subscription/newsletter, consider more aggressive archiving

workflows.userTask: Send a follow-up email to someone I emailed last week who hasn't responded

steps.purpose: Find the original sent email that needs follow-up

inputMapping.instructions: Find my sent email to this person from the past 2 weeks

steps.purpose: Check if there's been a reply
steps.logic: Look at the thread - if only one message exists, no reply received

steps.purpose: Create a polite follow-up message
steps.logic: Reference the original email subject, politely ask for update, keep it brief and professional

steps.purpose: Send the follow-up in the same thread

workflows.answerTemplate: I found your email to {step1.to.emails[0]} from {step1.date} with subject '{step1.subject}'. I've sent a follow-up in the same thread.
decisionPoints: If original email was less than 3 days ago, suggest waiting longer
If multiple unanswered emails exist, prioritize the oldest
Keep follow-up brief - 2-3 sentences maximum
Reference the original topic to provide context

workflows.userTask: Check my inbox for any security alerts or suspicious emails that need attention

steps.purpose: Find emails in the updates category (where security alerts typically land)
Identify security-related emails
steps.logic: Filter step1 for emails with subjects containing: 'security', 'alert', 'password', 'login', 'suspicious', 'verify', 'unauthorized', 'breach', or from known security senders (Google, banks, services)

steps.purpose: Get full content of security alerts

inputMapping.instructions: Get the full security alert content

steps.purpose: Assess threat level and required actions
steps.logic: For each alert: (1) Verify sender is legitimate (not phishing), (2) Identify what action is needed, (3) Prioritize by urgency

steps.purpose: Star high-priority security alerts

inputMapping.message_id: IDs of high-priority alerts from step 4

workflows.answerTemplate: I found {step2.count} security-related emails. {step4.high_priority} need immediate attention (starred). Key alerts: {step4.summary}
decisionPoints: If email asks for password/credentials via link, likely phishing - DO NOT click
Legitimate security alerts from Google come from specific verified addresses
Password breach notifications should trigger immediate password change
Login alerts from unfamiliar locations need account review

workflows.userTask: Find all promotional/newsletter emails and help me clean up my subscriptions

steps.purpose: Find all promotional emails

inputMapping.instructions: Find promotional emails from the past month

steps.purpose: Group emails by sender to identify frequent senders
steps.logic: Count emails per sender, identify: (1) senders with 5+ emails - high frequency, (2) senders with 2-4 emails - medium, (3) single emails - low. Note unsubscribe availability.

steps.purpose: Recommend which to keep vs unsubscribe
steps.logic: High frequency senders you haven't opened are candidates for unsubscribe. Keep if you've engaged with content recently.

steps.purpose: Delete old promotional emails to clean inbox

inputMapping.message_id: IDs of promotional emails older than 30 days

steps.purpose: Mark remaining promotions as read

inputMapping.message_id: IDs of promotions to keep but mark as read

workflows.answerTemplate: Found {step1.count} promotional emails from {step2.unique_senders} senders. Top senders: {step2.top_senders}. Deleted {step4.count} old emails. Recommendation: Consider unsubscribing from {step3.unsubscribe_candidates}.
decisionPoints: If sender emails more than weekly and you never open them, recommend unsubscribe
Keep receipts and order confirmations even if promotional
Delete promotional emails older than 30 days
Note: Actual unsubscribe requires clicking links in emails

insights:
This MCP provides comprehensive Gmail management through Zapier's integration. Key findings:

1. **Tool Categories**: The tools cover email finding/searching, label management, email organization (archive, delete), email composition (send, draft, reply), and attachment handling.

2. **Dependencies**: Most action tools (add label, archive, delete, reply) require a message_id from find_email. The thread_id is needed for conversation-level operations and replies.

3. **Query Power**: The gmail_find_email tool supports Gmail's full search syntax including operators like from:, to:, subject:, has:attachment, category:, is:unread, newer_than:, and boolean combinations.

4. **Label System**: Gmail uses both system labels (INBOX, STARRED, IMPORTANT, UNREAD, TRASH, CATEGORY_*) and custom labels (Label_1, etc.). The add/remove label tools work with both.

5. **Attachment Handling**: Attachments are accessible via find_email (which returns attachment metadata including URLs) and get_attachment_by_filename for specific file downloads.

6. **Email Composition**: Supports HTML body by default, multiple recipients (to, cc, bcc), and threading for replies. Draft creation allows review before sending.

7. **Instructions Field**: All tools have a required 'instructions' field that helps Zapier's AI fill in missing parameters - useful for natural language requests.

8. **Practical Workflows**: Created workflows for inbox triage, invoice collection, follow-up emails, security alert monitoring, and subscription cleanup - common real-world email management tasks.
